heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Müntzer, German mystic and theologian (b. 1488)

entities.title: Thomas Müntzer
entities.description: Thomas Müntzer was a German preacher and theologian of the early Reformation whose opposition to both Martin Luther and the Roman Catholic Church led to his open defiance of late-feudal authority in central Germany. Müntzer was foremost amongst those reformers who took issue with Luther's compromises with feudal authority. He became a leader of the German peasant and plebeian uprising of 1525 comm

heading: Deaths
txt: Margaret Pole, Countess of Salisbury (b. 1473)

entities.title: Margaret Pole, Countess of Salisbury
entities.description: Margaret Pole, Countess of Salisbury, was an English peeress. She was the daughter of George, Duke of Clarence, and Isabel Neville, the niece of kings Edward IV and Richard III. Margaret was one of two women in 16th-century England to be a peeress in her own right with no titled husband. One of the few surviving members of the Plantagenet dynasty after the Wars of the Roses, she was executed in 15

heading: Deaths
txt: John Calvin, French pastor and theologian (b. 1509)

entities.title: John Calvin
entities.description: John Calvin was a French theologian, pastor and reformer in Geneva during the Protestant Reformation. He was a principal figure in the development of the system of Christian theology later called Calvinism, including its doctrines of predestination and of God's absolute sovereignty in the salvation of the human soul from death and eternal damnation. Calvinist doctrines were influenced by and elabo

heading: Deaths
txt: François Ravaillac, French assassin of Henry IV of France (b. 1578)

entities.title: François Ravaillac
entities.description: François Ravaillac was a French Catholic zealot who assassinated King Henry IV of France in 1610.

entities.title: Henry IV of France
entities.description: Henry IV, also known by the epithet Good King Henry or Henry the Great, was King of Navarre from 1572 and King of France from 1589 to 1610. He was the first monarch of France from the House of Bourbon, a cadet branch of the Capetian dynasty. He was assassinated in 1610 by François Ravaillac, a fanatical Catholic, and was succeeded by his son Louis XIII.

heading: Deaths
txt: Diego Ramírez de Arellano, Spanish sailor and cosmographer (b. c. 1580)

entities.title: Diego Ramírez de Arellano
entities.description:
Diego Ramírez de Arellano was a Spanish sailor and cosmographer.
He achieved fame for piloting the Garcia de Nodal expedition to the region of the Strait of Magellan. The expedition discovered the Diego Ramírez Islands, the most southerly point visited by Europeans until the discovery of the South Sandwich Islands by Captain James Cook in 1775.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Boteler, 1st Baron Boteler of Brantfield, English politician (b. c. 1566)

entities.title: John Boteler, 1st Baron Boteler of Brantfield
entities.description: John Boteler, 1st Baron Boteler of Brantfield, was an English politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1625 to 1626. The Butlers of Hertfordshire claimed descent from Ralph le Boteler, butler to Robert de Beaumont, Count of Meulan and Earl of Leicester in the time of Henry I, and by the 15th century they had been seated at Watton for some time.

heading: Deaths
txt: Archibald Campbell, 1st Marquess of Argyll, Scottish general and politician (b. 1607)

entities.title: Archibald Campbell, 1st Marquess of Argyll
entities.description: Archibald Campbell, 1st Marquess of Argyll, 8th Earl of Argyll, Chief of Clan Campbell was a Scottish nobleman, politician, and peer. The de facto head of Scotland's government during most of the conflict of the 1640s and 50s known as the Wars of the Three Kingdoms, he was a major figure in the Covenanter movement that fought for the maintenance of the Presbyterian religion against the Stuart mona

heading: Deaths
txt: Gaspard Dughet, Italian-French painter (b. 1613)

entities.title: Gaspard Dughet
entities.description: Gaspard Dughet, also known as Gaspard Poussin, was a French painter born in Rome.

heading: Deaths
txt: Giovanni Legrenzi, Italian organist and composer (b. 1626)

entities.title: Giovanni Legrenzi
entities.description: Giovanni Legrenzi was an Italian composer of opera, vocal and instrumental music, and organist, of the Baroque era. He was one of the most prominent composers in Venice in the late 17th century, and extremely influential in the development of late Baroque idioms across northern Italy.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dominique Bouhours, French priest and critic (b. 1628)

entities.title: Dominique Bouhours
entities.description: Dominique Bouhours was a French Jesuit priest, essayist, grammarian, and neo-classical critic. He was born and died in Paris.

heading: Deaths
txt: Françoise-Athénaïs, marquise de Montespan, French mistress of Louis XIV of France (b. 1640)

entities.title: Françoise-Athénaïs, marquise de Montespan
entities.description: Françoise-Athénaïs de Rochechouart de Mortemart, Marquise of Montespan, better known as Madame de Montespan, was the most celebrated maîtresse-en-titre of King Louis XIV of France, by whom she had seven children.

entities.title: Louis XIV of France
entities.description: Louis XIV, also known as Louis the Great or the Sun King, was King of France from 14 May 1643 until his death in 1715. His reign of 72 years and 110 days is the longest recorded of any monarch of a sovereign country in European history. Louis XIV's France was emblematic of the age of absolutism in Europe. The King surrounded himself with a variety of significant political, military, and cultural f

heading: Deaths
txt: Giovanni Battista Beccaria, Italian physicist and academic (b. 1716)

entities.title: Giovanni Battista Beccaria
entities.description: Giovanni Battista Beccaria, Italian physicist, was born at Mondovì, and entered the religious Order of the Pious Schools or Piarists, in 1732, where he studied, and afterward taught, grammar and rhetoric. At the same time, he applied himself with success to mathematics.

heading: Deaths
txt: François-Noël Babeuf, French journalist (b. 1760)

entities.title: François-Noël Babeuf
entities.description: François-Noël Babeuf, also known as Gracchus Babeuf, was a French proto-socialist, revolutionary and journalist of the French Revolutionary period. His newspaper Le tribun du peuple was best known for its advocacy for the poor and calling for a popular revolt against the Directory, the government of France. He was a leading advocate for democracy and the abolition of private property. He angered t

heading: Deaths
txt: Jedediah Smith, American hunter, explorer, and author (b. 1799)

entities.title: Jedediah Smith
entities.description: Jedediah Strong Smith, was an American clerk, transcontinental pioneer, frontiersman, hunter, trapper, author, cartographer, and explorer of the Rocky Mountains, the North American West, and the Southwest during the early 19th century. After 75 years of obscurity following his death, Smith was rediscovered as the American whose explorations led to the use of the 20-mile (32 km)-wide South Pass as

heading: Deaths
txt: Niccolò Paganini, Italian violinist and composer (b. 1782)

entities.title: Niccolò Paganini
entities.description: Niccolò Paganini was an Italian violinist, violist, guitarist, and composer. He was the most celebrated violin virtuoso of his time, and left his mark as one of the pillars of modern violin technique. His 24 Caprices for Solo Violin Op. 1 are among the best known of his compositions, and have served as an inspiration for many prominent composers.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Bulfinch American mythologist (b. 1796)

entities.title: Thomas Bulfinch
entities.description: Thomas Bulfinch was an American writer born in Newton, Massachusetts, best known for the book Bulfinch's Mythology.

heading: Deaths
txt: Aleksandr Stoletov, Russian physicist, engineer, and academic (b. 1839)

entities.title: Aleksandr Stoletov
entities.description: Alexander Grigorievich Stoletov was a Russian physicist, founder of electrical engineering, and professor in Moscow University. He was the brother of general Nikolai Stoletov.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Koch, German physician and microbiologist, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1843)

entities.title: Robert Koch
entities.description: Heinrich Hermann Robert Koch was a German physician and microbiologist. As the discoverer of the specific causative agents of deadly infectious diseases including tuberculosis, cholera, and anthrax, he is regarded as one of the main founders of modern bacteriology. As such he is popularly nicknamed the father of microbiology, and as the father of medical bacteriology. His discovery of the anthrax

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ōzutsu Man'emon, Japanese sumo wrestler, the 18th Yokozuna (b. 1869)

entities.title: Ōzutsu Man'emon
entities.description: Ōzutsu Man'emon  was a Japanese professional sumo wrestler from Shiroishi, Miyagi Prefecture. He was the sport's 18th yokozuna.

entities.title: Makuuchi
entities.description: Makuuchi (幕内), or makunouchi (幕の内), is the top division of the six divisions of professional sumo. Its size is fixed at 42 wrestlers (rikishi), ordered into five ranks according to their ability as defined by their performance in previous tournaments.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kandukuri Veeresalingam, Indian author and activist (b. 1848)

entities.title: Kandukuri Veeresalingam
entities.description: Rao Bahadur Kandukuri Veeresalingam Pantulu was a social reformer and writer from the Madras Presidency, British India. He is considered as the father of the Telugu Renaissance movement. He was one of the early social reformers who encouraged the education of women and the remarriage of widows. He also fought against child marriage and the dowry system. He started a school in Dowlaiswaram in 1874.

heading: Deaths
txt: Achille Paroche, French target shooter (b. 1868)

entities.title: Achille Paroche
entities.description: Nicolas Achille Paroche was a French sport shooter who competed in the 1900 Summer Olympics and 1920 Summer Olympics.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Roth, Austrian-French journalist and author (b. 1894)

entities.title: Joseph Roth
entities.description: Joseph Roth, born Moses Joseph Roth, was an Austrian journalist and novelist, best known for his family saga Radetzky March (1932), about the decline and fall of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, his novel of Jewish life Job (1930) and his seminal essay "Juden auf Wanderschaft", a fragmented account of the Jewish migrations from eastern to western Europe in the aftermath of World War I and the Russian

heading: Deaths
txt: Ernst Lindemann, German captain (b. 1894)

entities.title: Ernst Lindemann
entities.description: Otto Ernst Lindemann was a German Kapitän zur See. He was the only commander of the battleship Bismarck during its eight months of service in World War II.

heading: Deaths
txt: Günther Lütjens, German admiral (b. 1889)

heading: Deaths
txt: Muhammed Hamdi Yazır, Turkish theologian, logician, and translator (b. 1878)

entities.title: Muhammed Hamdi Yazır
entities.description: Muhammed Hamdi Yazır also known as Elmalılı Hamdi Yazır and Elmalılı was a Turkish Maturidi theologian, logician, Qur'an translator, Qur'anic exegesis scholar, Islamic legal academic, philosopher and encyclopedist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gordon Coates, New Zealand soldier and politician, 21st Prime Minister of New Zealand (b. 1878)

entities.title: Gordon Coates
entities.description: Joseph Gordon Coates served as the 21st Prime Minister of New Zealand from 1925 to 1928. He was the third successive Reform prime minister since 1912.

entities.title: Prime Minister of New Zealand
entities.description: The prime minister of New Zealand is the head of government of New Zealand. The incumbent prime minister, Jacinda Ardern, leader of the New Zealand Labour Party, took office on 26 October 2017.

heading: Deaths
txt: Enno Lolling, German physician  (b. 1888)

entities.title: Enno Lolling
entities.description: Enno Lolling was a Nazi doctor. As a member of the SS, he served as a Lagerarzt at Dachau concentration camp. He later headed up the medical division for all the SS concentration camps. Lolling committed suicide in Flensburg as the war was ending.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ed Konetchy, American baseball player and manager (b. 1885)

entities.title: Ed Konetchy
entities.description: Edward Joseph Konetchy, nicknamed "Big Ed" and "The Candy Kid", was an American first baseman in Major League Baseball for a number of teams, primarily in the National League, from 1907 to 1921. He played for the St. Louis Cardinals (1907–1913), Pittsburgh Pirates (1914), Pittsburgh Rebels of the Federal League (1915), Boston Braves (1916–1918), Brooklyn Robins (1919–1921), and Philadelphia Philli

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Ripley, American cartoonist, publisher, and businessman, founded Ripley's Believe It or Not! (b. 1890)

entities.title: Robert Ripley
entities.description: LeRoy Robert Ripley was an American cartoonist, entrepreneur and amateur anthropologist who is known for creating the Ripley's Believe It or Not! newspaper panel series, television show and radio show which feature odd facts from around the world.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jesse Burkett, American baseball player and manager (b. 1868)

entities.title: Jesse Burkett
entities.description: Jesse Cail Burkett, nicknamed "Crab", was an American professional baseball left fielder. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) from 1890 to 1905 for the New York Giants, Cleveland Spiders, St. Louis Perfectos / Cardinals, St. Louis Browns, and Boston Americans.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Montgomery Flagg, American painter and illustrator (b. 1877)

entities.title: James Montgomery Flagg
entities.description: James Montgomery Flagg was an American artist, comics artist and illustrator. He worked in media ranging from fine art painting to cartooning, but is best remembered for his political posters.

heading: Deaths
txt: Grigoris Lambrakis, Greek physician and politician (b. 1912)

entities.title: Grigoris Lambrakis
entities.description: Grigoris Lambrakis was a Greek politician, physician, track and field athlete, and member of the faculty of the School of Medicine at the University of Athens. A member of the Greek resistance to Axis rule during WWII, he later became a prominent anti-war activist. His assassination by right-wing zealots provoked mass protests and led to a political crisis.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jawaharlal Nehru, Indian lawyer and politician, 1st Prime Minister of India (b. 1889)

entities.title: Jawaharlal Nehru
entities.description: Jawaharlal Nehru was an Indian independence activist and, subsequently, the first Prime Minister of India, as well as a central figure in Indian politics both before and after independence. He emerged as an eminent leader of the Indian independence movement, serving India as Prime Minister from its establishment in 1947 as an independent nation, until his death in 1964. He was also known as Pandit

entities.title: Prime Minister of India
entities.description: The Prime Minister of India, officially the Prime Minister of the Republic of India, is the leader of the executive branch of the Government of India. The prime minister is the chief adviser to the President of India and the head of the Union Council of Ministers. They can be a member of any of the two houses of the Parliament of India—the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha ; but has to be a member of

heading: Deaths
txt: W. Otto Miessner, American composer and educator (b. 1880)

entities.title: W. Otto Miessner
entities.description: William Otto Miessner was an American composer and music educator. Most of his life was spent in the midwest, particularly Indiana and Wisconsin.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ernst Niekisch, German academic and politician (b. 1889)

heading: Deaths
txt: Jeffrey Hunter, American actor and producer (b. 1926)

entities.title: Jeffrey Hunter
entities.description: Jeffrey Hunter was an American film and television actor and producer known for his roles in films such as The Searchers and King of Kings. On television, Hunter was known for his 1965 role as Capt. Christopher Pike in the original pilot episode of Star Trek and the later use of that footage in "The Menagerie."

heading: Deaths
txt: Béla Juhos, Hungarian-Austrian philosopher from the Vienna Circle (b. 1901)

entities.title: Béla Juhos
entities.description: Béla Juhos was a Hungarian-Austrian philosopher and member of the Vienna Circle.

heading: Deaths
txt: Armando Picchi, Italian footballer and coach (b. 1935)

heading: Deaths
txt: Gün Sazak, Turkish agronomist and politician (b. 1932)

entities.title: Gün Sazak
entities.description: Gün Sazak was a Turkish nationalist politician and former government minister of the Nationalist Movement Party (MHP). He was assassinated by the Revolutionary People's Liberation Party/Front after his police guard was removed. After his killing, MHP supporters carried out the Çorum massacre in reprisal.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vasilije Mokranjac, Serbian composer (b. 1923)

entities.title: Vasilije Mokranjac
entities.description: Vasilije Mokranjac was a Serbian composer, professor of composition at the Faculty of Music in Belgrade and a member of the Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts. He was one of the most prominent Serbian composers in the second half of the 20th century. Although famed for his symphonies, he also wrote piano music, as well as music for radio, film and theatre. He won the most prestigious awards in f

heading: Deaths
txt: Ismail al-Faruqi, Palestinian-American philosopher and academic (b. 1921)

entities.title: Ismail al-Faruqi
entities.description: Ismaʻīl Rājī al-Fārūqī was a Palestinian-American philosopher, widely recognised by his peers as an authority on Islam and comparative religion. He spent several years at Al-Azhar University in Cairo, then taught at several universities in North America, including McGill University in Montreal. He was Professor of Religion at Temple University, where he founded and chaired the Islamic Studies prog

heading: Deaths
txt: Ajoy Mukherjee, Indian politician, Chief Minister of West Bengal (b. 1901)

entities.title: Chief Minister of West Bengal
entities.description: The Chief Minister of West Bengal is the chief executive of the eastern Indian state of West Bengal. The chief minister is the head of the executive branch of the government of West Bengal and is charged with enforcing state laws. Following elections to the West Bengal Legislative Assembly, the state's governor usually invites the party with a majority of seats to form the government. The governor

heading: Deaths
txt: Giorgos Tzifos, Greek actor and cinematographer (b. 1918)

heading: Deaths
txt: John Howard Northrop, American biochemist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1891)

entities.title: John Howard Northrop
entities.description: John Howard Northrop was an American biochemist who, with James Batcheller Sumner and Wendell Meredith Stanley, won the 1946 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. The award was given for these scientists' isolation, crystallization, and study of enzymes, proteins, and viruses. Northrop was a Professor of Bacteriology and Medical Physics, Emeritus, at University of California, Berkeley.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. This award is administered by the Nobel Foundation, and awarded by t

heading: Deaths
txt: Hjördis Petterson, Swedish actress (b. 1908)

entities.title: Hjördis Petterson
entities.description: Hjördis Olga Maria Petterson was a Swedish actress. She has appeared in more than 140 films. She was born in Visby, Sweden and died in Stockholm.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ernst Ruska, German physicist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1906)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics

heading: Deaths
txt: Arseny Tarkovsky, Russian poet and translator (b. 1907)

entities.title: Arseny Tarkovsky
entities.description: Arseny Aleksandrovich Tarkovsky was a Soviet Russian poet and translator, considered one of the great twentieth century Russian poets. He was predeceased by his son, film director Andrei Tarkovsky.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert B. Meyner, American lawyer and politician, 44th Governor of New Jersey (b. 1908)

entities.title: Robert B. Meyner
entities.description: Robert Baumle Meyner was an American Democratic Party politician, who served as the 44th Governor of New Jersey, from 1954 to 1962. Before being elected governor, Meyner represented Warren County in the New Jersey Senate from 1948 to 1951.

entities.title: Governor of New Jersey
entities.description: The Governor of the State of New Jersey is head of the executive branch of New Jersey's state government. The office of governor is an elected position, for which elected officials serve four-year terms. heading: Deaths
txt: Leopold Nowak, Austrian musicologist and theorist (b. 1904)

entities.title: Leopold Nowak
entities.description: Leopold Nowak was a musicologist chiefly known for editing the works of Anton Bruckner for the International Bruckner Society. He reconstructed the original form of some of those works, most of which had been revised and edited many times.

heading: Deaths
txt: Uncle Charlie Osborne, American fiddler (b. 1890)

entities.title: Uncle Charlie Osborne
entities.description: Charles Nelson Osborne, affectionately known as "Uncle Charlie," was a musician in the Appalachian Mountains of southwest Virginia. He was born in what is now known as Cowan Osborne Hollow, named for his father, in Copper Creek, Virginia. He was regionally famous from the time he was about 15 until his death at age 101 in 1992.

heading: Deaths
txt: Minoo Masani, Indian lawyer and politician (b. 1905)

entities.title: Minoo Masani
entities.description: Minocher Rustom "Minoo" Masani was an Indian politician, a leading figure of the erstwhile Swatantra Party. He was a three-time Member of Parliament, representing Gujarat's Rajkot constituency in the second, third and fourth Lok Sabha. A Parsi, he was among the founders of the Indian Liberal Group think tank that promoted classical liberalism.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kazimierz Leski, Polish engineer and pilot (b. 1912)

entities.title: Kazimierz Leski
entities.description: Kazimierz Leski, nom de guerre Bradl, was a Polish engineer, co-designer of the Polish submarines ORP Sęp (1938) and ORP Orzeł, a fighter pilot, and an officer in World War II Home Army's intelligence and counter-intelligence.

heading: Deaths
txt: Murray MacLehose, Baron MacLehose of Beoch, Scottish politician and diplomat, 25th Governor of Hong Kong (b. 1917)

entities.title: Governor of Hong Kong
entities.description: The Governor of Hong Kong was the representative of the British Crown in Hong Kong from 1843 to 1997. In this capacity, the governor was president of the Executive Council and Commander-in-Chief of the British Forces Overseas Hong Kong. txt: Maurice Richard, Canadian ice hockey player and coach (b. 1921)

heading: Deaths
txt: Luciano Berio, Italian composer and educator (b. 1925)

entities.title: Luciano Berio
entities.description: Luciano Berio OMRI was an Italian composer noted for his experimental work, and for his pioneering work in electronic music. His early work was influenced by Igor Stravinsky and experiments with serial and electronic techniques, while his later works explore indeterminacy and the use of spoken texts as the basic material for composition.

heading: Deaths
txt: Rob Borsellino, American journalist (b. 1949)

entities.title: Rob Borsellino
entities.description: Rob Borsellino was a newspaper columnist who worked for the Des Moines Register. His columns, which appeared three times weekly, became popular due to Borsellino's colloquial writing style and ability to tell a story straight from the heart. heading: Deaths

heading: Deaths
txt: Izumi Sakai, Japanese singer-songwriter (b. 1967)

entities.title: Izumi Sakai
entities.description: Sachiko Kamachi , known professionally as Izumi Sakai , was a female Japanese pop singer, songwriter, and member of the group Zard. As Sakai was the only member who stayed in the group while others joined and left regularly, Zard and Sakai may be referred to interchangeably. heading: Deaths

entities.title: Hot air balloon
entities.description: A hot-air balloon is a lighter-than-air aircraft consisting of a bag, called an envelope, which contains heated air. Suspended beneath is a gondola or wicker basket, which carries passengers and a source of heat, in most cases an open flame caused by burning liquid propane. The heated air inside the envelope makes it buoyant, since it has a lower density than the colder air outside the envelope. A

heading: Deaths
txt: Franz Künstler, Hungarian soldier (b. 1900)

entities.title: Franz Künstler
entities.description: Franz Künstler was, at age 107, the last known surviving veteran of the First World War who fought for the Austro-Hungarian Empire. Following the death of 110-year-old Ottoman veteran Yakup Satar on 2 April 2008, he was also the last Central Powers veteran of any nationality. He was born in Sósd, in the Kingdom of Hungary, now Măureni, Romania.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas M. Franck, American lawyer and academic (b. 1931)

entities.title: Thomas M. Franck
entities.description: Thomas Martin Franck was a lawyer, law professor, and expert on international law. Franck was the Murry and Ida Becker Professor of Law at New York University and advised many nations on legal matters, even helping some to write their constitutions.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Genn, Canadian painter and author (b. 1936)

entities.title: Robert Genn
entities.description: Robert Douglas Genn was a Canadian artist, who gained recognition for his style, which is in the tradition of Canadian landscape painting. He ran a painters' website, which sends out twice weekly newsletters to 135,000 artists. heading: Deaths
txt: Gregg Allman, American musician, singer and songwriter (b. 1947)

entities.title: Gregg Allman
entities.description: Gregory LeNoir Allman was an American singer-songwriter and musician. He was known for performing in the Allman Brothers Band. Allman grew up with an interest in rhythm and blues music, and the Allman Brothers Band fused it with rock music, jazz, and country at times. heading: Deaths
txt: Larry Kramer, American playwright, public health advocate and LGBT rights activist (b. 1935)

entities.title: Larry Kramer
entities.description: Laurence David Kramer was an American playwright, author, film producer, public health advocate, and LGBT rights activist. He began his career rewriting scripts while working for Columbia Pictures, which led him to London, where he worked with United Artists. There he wrote the screenplay for the film Women in Love (1969) and received an Academy Award nomination for his work.
